metadata.titleEn: One belt, one road, key node area,inter-annual change process data of built-up areas (1985-2018)
metadata.description: The change of urban built-up area reflects the development of the city, so the information extraction of the change process of built-up area is an important prerequisite for the study of urban development and regional economy. This data set contains the annual change information of the built-up area of key nodes from 1985 to 2018, with a resolution of 30m. Using the combined method of supervision classification and time consistency check, the three key nodes of Hambantota, Yangon and Dhaka are used as the study area to determine the change from the non-built-up area to the built-up area. Pixels in built-up areas are defined as more than 50% impervious. The year of transition (from non-built-up area to built-up area) can be identified from the pixel value, ranging from 34 (year: 1985) to 1 (year: 2018). For example, the built-up area in 1990 can be displayed with a pixel value greater than 29. After monotonous conversion from non-built-up area to built-up area, the data set is consistent in time.
metadata.instructions: In .tif format, can be opened and analysed in ARCGIS and ENVI softwares.

background: Artiﬁcial impervious areas are predominant indicators of human settlements. Timely, accurate, and frequent information on artiﬁcial impervious areas is critical to understanding the process of urbanization and land use/cover change, as well as of their impacts on the environment and biodiversity. The change of global artiﬁcial impervious area (GAIA) is a critical indicator for understanding the impact of global urbanization on human society and the environment. Artiﬁcial impervious areas are mainly man-made structures that are composed of any material that impedes or prevents natural inﬁltration of water into the soil. As an important proxy to built-up areas in the world, artiﬁcial impervious areas play a critical role in controlling the ﬂows of energy and materials and reﬂecting various levels of human activities. The rapid urban growth worldwide has signiﬁcant local and tele-connected impacts on biodiversity loss, agricultural production, and environmental quality, all of which ﬁnally inﬂuence human health and well-being. Although studies of mapping urban built-up areas and artiﬁcial impervious areas using satellite observations started more than four decades ago, earlier efforts were mainly made at the local scale. Since 2005, the advent of freely accessible satellite data made it possible to map urban extent and artiﬁcial impervious areas at the global scale. Despite many existing efforts in mapping GAIA, annual maps covering a relatively long period of time (i.e., more than 30 years) do not exist. In fact, accurate annual global land cover information including GAIA is needed in global climate change studies.
research objective: The purpose of this research was to develop a 34-year long annual GAIA using the full archive of Landsat data from 1985 to 2018.
challenges: Our previous studies suggest the mapping performance in arid and semi-arid regions is relatively poor due to the highly confusing spectral information between the artiﬁcial impervious area and the surrounding bare lands, resulting in an over commission of artiﬁcial impervious areas in dryland regions.
methods: We developed an automatic mapping procedure on the Google Earth Engine (GEE) platform to implement the planetary-scale mapping of annual artiﬁcial impervious areas at a 30-m resolution from 1985 to 2018. Therefore, in this research, we divided the whole world into arid areas and non-arid areas according to the global biome map. For non-arid areas, we used the same approach as in our previous studies. In arid regions, we developed an improved algorithm by including additional constraints to mitigate the overestimation caused by spectral confusion between impervious areas and bare lands. To improve the mapping eﬃciency on the GEE, we divided the whole world into 583 geographical grids (3.5º×3.5°), of which 155 grids contain arid biomes. The mapping procedures were implemented in all grids, using the full archive of Landsat time series images.
dataset: All Landsat Thematic Mapper (TM), Enhanced Thematic Mapper Plus (ETM+), and Landsat 8 Operational Land Imager (OLI) data acquired in different years were collected and processed for mapping of artificial impervious areas. Training samples of the impervious area are needed when applying the “Exclusion-Inclusion” algorithm. These sample units (i.e., around 100 per grid) were collected from earlier Landsat images (i.e., near or around the start year of 1985) in reference with higher resolution images in Google Earth; thus they can be spatially and temporally extended to enrich the sample size and applied to subsequent years.
findings: Our results indicate that the GAIA reached 797,076 km2 in 2018, which is 1.5 times more than that in 1990. China and the United States (US) rank among the top two in artiﬁcial impervious area, accounting for approximately 50% of the world's total in 2018. The artiﬁcial impervious area of China surpassed that of the US in 2015.

Example.Question: What is an example of a challenge encountered in mapping artificial impervious areas in arid regions?
Example.Answer: A challenge in mapping artificial impervious areas in arid regions is the highly confusing spectral information between the artificial impervious area and the surrounding bare lands, which results in overestimation of impervious areas.

Example.Question: Could you illustrate an example of how a dataset on artificial impervious areas might be expanded or refined over time?
Example.Answer: A dataset can be expanded or refined by collecting and processing Landsat Thematic Mapper (TM), Enhanced Thematic Mapper Plus (ETM+), and Landsat 8 Operational Land Imager (OLI) data from different years, and using training samples collected from earlier images to apply to subsequent years, thereby enriching the sample size.

Definition.Question: What is the 'Exclusion-Inclusion' algorithm used in the context of mapping artificial impervious areas?
Definition.Answer: The 'Exclusion-Inclusion' algorithm is a methodology used for mapping artificial impervious areas, where training samples of the impervious area are collected to apply the algorithm. These sample units are initially gathered from earlier satellite images and can be spatially and temporally extended to enrich the sample size for subsequent years.

Definition.Question: What does 'supervised classification' mean in the context of urban development data analysis?
Definition.Answer: In the context of urban development data analysis, 'supervised classification' refers to a technique that involves using labeled data to train a model to differentiate between various classes or categories. This method is part of a combination approach used to determine changes from non-built-up to built-up areas in urban studies.

Definition.Question: What is meant by 'spectral confusion' in remote sensing of artificial impervious areas?
Definition.Answer: In remote sensing, 'spectral confusion' refers to the difficulty in distinguishing between artificial impervious areas and surrounding bare lands due to similar spectral characteristics, particularly in arid and semi-arid regions. This confusion can lead to overestimation of impervious areas in dryland regions.

Comparison.Question: How does the method of mapping urban built-up areas using satellite observations compare to the automatic mapping procedure developed on the Google Earth Engine platform for artificial impervious areas?
Comparison.Answer: Mapping urban built-up areas using satellite observations traditionally involved efforts at a local scale, while the automatic mapping procedure on the Google Earth Engine platform facilitates planetary-scale mapping of annual artificial impervious areas at a 30-meter resolution from 1985 to 2018, offering a global perspective.

Comparison.Question: What are the differences in challenges faced when mapping artificial impervious areas in arid versus non-arid regions?
Comparison.Answer: In arid regions, the mapping performance is relatively poor due to spectral confusion between artificial impervious areas and surrounding bare lands, necessitating additional constraints to mitigate overestimation. In contrast, non-arid regions do not face this challenge, allowing the use of approaches from previous studies without these additional constraints.

Interpretation.Question: What challenges might arise in differentiating artificial impervious areas from natural landscapes in arid and semi-arid regions, and how can these be addressed in data collection methodologies?
Interpretation.Answer: In arid and semi-arid regions, the spectral similarity between artificial impervious areas and surrounding bare lands poses a challenge, often leading to overestimation. This can be addressed by incorporating additional constraints and developing improved algorithms that can better differentiate between these features, thus enhancing the accuracy of mapping impervious areas.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What factors contribute to the overestimation of artificial impervious areas in arid and semi-arid regions when using satellite data for mapping?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The mapping performance in arid and semi-arid regions is relatively poor due to the highly confusing spectral information between the artificial impervious area and the surrounding bare lands, resulting in an over commission of artificial impervious areas in dryland regions.

Causal Antecedent.Question: Why is the development of a long-term annual global dataset of artificial impervious areas crucial for global climate change studies?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Accurate annual global land cover information, including global artificial impervious areas (GAIA), is needed in global climate change studies to understand the impact of global urbanization on human society and the environment.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What challenges does the spectral confusion between artificial impervious areas and surrounding environments pose in mapping efforts, and how can these be addressed?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The spectral confusion between artificial impervious areas and surrounding bare lands in arid regions causes overestimation of impervious areas. This challenge can be addressed by including additional constraints in the mapping algorithm to mitigate the overestimation caused by spectral confusion.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the consequences of using a combination of supervised classification and time consistency checks on the accuracy of urban built-up area mapping?
Causal Consequence.Answer: The use of a combination of supervised classification and time consistency checks helps in accurately determining changes from non-built-up to built-up areas, which reflects urban development effectively. It ensures temporal consistency in detecting changes across years, thereby improving the reliability of urban area mapping over time.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the potential effects of including additional constraints in mapping algorithms on the accuracy of impervious area identification in arid regions?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Including additional constraints in mapping algorithms for arid regions can mitigate overestimation caused by spectral confusion between impervious areas and bare lands, thereby improving mapping accuracy. This adjustment addresses the challenge of distinguishing between similar spectral signatures, leading to more precise identification of impervious surfaces in these challenging environments.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why is it significant to address the mapping performance challenges in arid and semi-arid regions when creating datasets of artificial impervious areas?
Goal Orientation.Answer: Addressing the mapping performance challenges in arid and semi-arid regions is significant because of the highly confusing spectral information between artificial impervious areas and surrounding bare lands, which results in overestimation of impervious areas. This needs to be mitigated for accurate mapping.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What procedural steps are involved in the automatic mapping of artificial impervious areas using satellite data on the Google Earth Engine platform?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The procedure involves developing an automatic mapping process on the Google Earth Engine (GEE) platform for planetary-scale mapping of annual artificial impervious areas at a 30-m resolution from 1985 to 2018. The world is divided into arid and non-arid areas according to the global biome map, and different approaches are applied based on these categories. For arid regions, additional constraints are included to mitigate overestimation caused by spectral confusion. The world is divided into 583 geographical grids (3.5º×3.5°), and mapping procedures are implemented using the full archive of Landsat time series images.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What methodological improvements are made to mitigate the challenges of mapping artificial impervious areas in arid and semi-arid regions?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: In arid and semi-arid regions, an improved algorithm is developed by including additional constraints to address the challenge of spectral confusion between impervious areas and surrounding bare lands. This helps mitigate the overestimation of artificial impervious areas in dryland regions, enhancing the mapping accuracy.

Enablement.Question: How does the division of the world into arid and non-arid areas enhance the accuracy of mapping artificial impervious areas?
Enablement.Answer: The division of the world into arid and non-arid areas enhances the accuracy by allowing for the development of an improved algorithm in arid regions, where additional constraints are included to mitigate the overestimation caused by spectral confusion between impervious areas and bare lands.

Enablement.Question: What methods are employed to ensure the spatial and temporal extension of training samples for mapping artificial impervious areas?
Enablement.Answer: Training samples of the impervious area are collected from earlier Landsat images near the start year of 1985, in reference with higher resolution images in Google Earth, allowing them to be spatially and temporally extended to enrich the sample size and applied to subsequent years.

Expectation.Question: Why might the mapping performance in arid and semi-arid regions be relatively poor when using existing data collection methods for artificial impervious areas?
Expectation.Answer: Mapping performance in arid and semi-arid regions may be poor due to the highly confusing spectral information between the artificial impervious area and the surrounding bare lands, which results in an over commission of artificial impervious areas in dryland regions.

Expectation.Question: Why is there a need for accurate annual global land cover information, including artificial impervious areas, in global climate change studies?
Expectation.Answer: Accurate annual global land cover information, including artificial impervious areas, is needed in global climate change studies to understand the impact of global urbanization on human society and the environment, as well as to provide critical indicators for understanding the process of urbanization and land use/cover change.

Expectation.Question: What challenges might arise when developing an automatic mapping procedure to measure annual changes in artificial impervious areas?
Expectation.Answer: Challenges in developing an automatic mapping procedure to measure annual changes in artificial impervious areas can include mitigating overestimation caused by spectral confusion, especially in arid regions, and efficiently processing large volumes of satellite data across different geographical grids.

Judgmental.Question: What are the potential challenges in accurately mapping artificial impervious areas in arid regions using satellite data?
Judgmental.Answer: The potential challenges in accurately mapping artificial impervious areas in arid regions using satellite data include the highly confusing spectral information between the artificial impervious area and the surrounding bare lands. This can result in an over commission of artificial impervious areas in dryland regions.

Judgmental.Question: How effective do you find the use of the Google Earth Engine platform for planetary-scale mapping of urban built-up areas?
Judgmental.Answer: The use of the Google Earth Engine platform for planetary-scale mapping is considered effective as it allows the implementation of mapping procedures at a 30-m resolution from 1985 to 2018. It facilitates processing large volumes of Landsat data efficiently by dividing the world into geographical grids and applying improved algorithms in arid regions.

Judgmental.Question: Could the inclusion of higher resolution imagery in the training sample collection enhance the mapping of artificial impervious areas?
Judgmental.Answer: Yes, the inclusion of higher resolution imagery in the training sample collection could enhance the mapping of artificial impervious areas, as it provides more accurate reference points for comparison. This helps in spatially and temporally extending the sample size and applying it to subsequent years, which could improve the overall accuracy of the mapping process.

Assertion.Question: I don't understand how the mapping of artificial impervious areas could be accomplished on a global scale given the spectral confusion in arid regions.
Assertion.Answer: To address the spectral confusion in arid regions, an improved algorithm with additional constraints was developed to mitigate overestimation. The world was divided into arid and non-arid areas, and the mapping procedures were implemented using the full archive of Landsat time series images, leveraging the Google Earth Engine platform.

Assertion.Question: I'm unsure about how training samples for these artificial impervious areas are accurately collected and extended over time.
Assertion.Answer: Training samples of the impervious area were collected using earlier Landsat images and were referenced with higher resolution images in Google Earth. These sample units, around 100 per grid, are spatially and temporally extended to enrich the sample size and are applied to subsequent years.

Request/Directive.Question: Please outline the process of selecting and preparing training samples for mapping artificial impervious areas using Landsat data.
Request/Directive.Answer: Training samples of the impervious area are collected from earlier Landsat images near or around the start year of 1985, referencing higher resolution images in Google Earth. Approximately 100 sample units per geographical grid are collected and spatially and temporally extended to enrich the sample size for application to subsequent years.

Request/Directive.Question: Please evaluate the effectiveness of using Landsat data in mapping the global artificial impervious area over multiple decades and discuss any significant findings.
Request/Directive.Answer: Landsat data, including Thematic Mapper (TM), Enhanced Thematic Mapper Plus (ETM+), and Landsat 8 Operational Land Imager (OLI), are effective in mapping the global artificial impervious area over 34 years. A significant finding is that the global artificial impervious area reached 797,076 km2 in 2018, 1.5 times more than in 1990, with China and the US accounting for approximately 50% of the world's total in 2018.
